verses.text: Therefore, since we have been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Paul teaches that justification comes through faith, resulting in reconciliation with God. The mention of 'peace with God' echoes Isaiah 32:17, indicating a deep, restored relationship established by Christ. Many see this as both a legal declaration before God and the beginning of transformation in the believer.

verses.text: Through Him we have also obtained access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
verses.comment: The grace by which we stand refers to a present, continual state enabled by Christ. 'Access' hints at priestly language, drawing a connection between the believer and God, not just a one-time event but an ongoing relationship. The hope of glory suggests not only future resurrection but a share in divine life.

verses.text: And not only that, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance;
verses.comment: Christian life is marked by a paradoxical joy in sufferings. This echoes James 1:2-4, showing that trials bear spiritual fruit. Early Christians often understood suffering as participation in Christ's own Passion, drawing the believer closer to His life.

verses.text: and endurance produces character, and character produces hope.
verses.comment: Paul describes a chain of spiritual growth: hardship refines virtue, which in turn strengthens hope. This hope is not wishful thinking but a confident trust in God's promise.

verses.text: And hope does not disappoint, because God's love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who has been given to us.
verses.comment: The Spirit's indwelling is a fulfillment of Old Testament promises, such as in Ezekiel. The pouring of love is sacramental, indicating God's grace is not distant but experienced inwardly, fostering certainty in hope. Note the reference to the Holy Spirit as a real, ongoing gift.

verses.text: For while we were still weak, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly.
verses.comment: Christ's death is for the 'ungodly'—all humanity in need of salvation. 'At the right time' indicates divine providence. Isaiah 53 is a direct background for the atoning death of the Messiah.

verses.text: For one will scarcely die for a righteous person—though perhaps for a good person one would even dare to die—
verses.comment: Paul contrasts human love with divine love. Rare sacrifices for upright people exist, but what follows shows God's love is greater.

verses.text: but God shows His own love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
verses.comment: The radical nature of Christ's atoning death is highlighted—it occurs out of unmerited love. This points toward an unearned, supernatural grace at work.

verses.text: Much more then, since we have now been justified by His blood, we shall be saved from wrath through Him.
verses.comment: ‘Justified by His blood’ emphasizes the sacrificial, atoning aspect of Christ's death. The saving from wrath looks forward to final judgment. This justification and salvation is something continuous and transformative, not merely a past declaration.

verses.text: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, now that we are reconciled, shall we be saved by His life.
verses.comment: Reconciliation is not just a one-time event but an ongoing relationship. Salvation isn’t only through Christ’s death, but also through His risen life, which continues to intercede for us (Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: Not only this, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received reconciliation.
verses.comment: Receiving reconciliation is a present reality. This joy is a mark of true Christian life. The relational aspect of salvation is emphasized, not just a legal verdict.

verses.text: Therefore, just as sin entered the world through one man, and death through sin, and so death spread to all men, because all sinned—
verses.comment: Paul alludes to Adam's original sin—the idea that sin and death are inherited realities affecting all. This forms the basis for seeing a universal need for redemption. The implications for human nature and the universality of sin form the foundation for the doctrine of grace.

verses.text: for sin was in the world before the law was given, but sin is not counted where there is no law.
verses.comment: Even before Moses, human beings sinned. Yet the giving of the law clarified and heightened man's accountability. Paul is careful to distinguish between sin's presence and its legal reckoning.

verses.text: Nevertheless, death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those whose sins were not like the transgression of Adam, who was a type of the one to come.
verses.comment: Adam is described as a type—a foreshadowing—of Christ. This sets up a crucial New Testament theme of Christ as the new Adam, reversing Adam’s failure.

verses.text: But the free gift is not like the trespass. For if many died by the trespass of one man, much more did the grace of God and the gift by the grace of that one man, Jesus Christ, overflow to many.
verses.comment: Christ not only undoes Adam's sin—the grace He gives is overabundant. The language of gift emphasizes the superabundant nature of God's work through Christ.

verses.text: Nor is the gift like the result of that one man's sin. For the judgment following one trespass brought condemnation, but the free gift following many trespasses brought justification.
verses.comment: While Adam’s sin led to widespread condemnation, Christ’s gift extends justification even after countless sins. The effectiveness of Christ’s work far surpasses the effects of Adam's fall.

verses.text: For if, by the trespass of one man, death reigned through that one man, much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one man, Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: Believers ‘reign in life’—not only a future hope, but a present participation in Christ’s victory. This shares in the New Creation theme central to Paul's teaching. The grace is abundant and kingdom-like.

verses.text: Therefore, as one trespass led to condemnation for all men, so also one act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all men.
verses.comment: Adam's act brings condemnation, Christ’s obedience brings life. 'Justification and life' together suggest not only God’s favor, but a real restoration to spiritual life. Christ's single obedient act is His Passion and death.

verses.text: For just as through the disobedience of one man many were made sinners, so through the obedience of the one man many will be made righteous.
verses.comment: Christ’s obedience is linked to His Passion (Phil. 2:8). 'Made righteous' is a transformative process, not instantaneous. There is a real change in the life of the believer, echoing prophetic promises.

verses.text: Now the law came in so that the trespass might increase; but where sin increased, grace abounded much more,
verses.comment: The Law clarifies and intensifies sin, but God's response is to provide even more abundant grace. This principle will be spelled out further regarding the purpose of the Law and justification.

verses.text: so that, just as sin reigned in death, so also grace might reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.comment: Grace is seen as a new reigning power, leading not only to justification but culminating in eternal life—a life that begins now and finds fulfillment in union with Christ. Eternal life is both a future hope and a present possession rooted in union with Christ, as reflected in John 17.
